Graph (ciga)¶

This module provides the core TGraph class for managing and analyzing temporal graphs using the igraph library. It enables efficient handling of time-based social interaction data.

Classes¶

class ciga.TGraph(init_graph=None, data=None, position=None, directed=True)[source]¶

Bases: object

TGraph is a class for managing and analyzing temporal graphs using the igraph library.

data¶

The dataset containing graph edges and their attributes.

Type:

pd.DataFrame

_position¶

The positional indices used for temporal positioning in the data.

Type:

tuple

_layout¶

The layout of the graph (currently unused).

Type:

Any

_directed¶

Indicates whether the graph is directed.

Type:

bool

_vnames¶

List of vertex names.

Type:

list

name_to_id¶

Mapping from vertex names to their IDs.

Type:

dict

id_to_name¶

Mapping from vertex IDs to their names.

Type:

dict

_cache_graph¶

Cached version of the graph for performance optimization.

Type:

Graph

_cache_time_point¶

Cached time point corresponding to the cached graph.

Type:

tuple

get_delta_graph(start=None, end=None, *, delta_of_normalized=False, normalize_weight=False, invert_weight=False, fade_function=None, fade_step=None)[source]¶

Computes the delta (difference) between two graph states over a time interval.

Parameters:

  • start (tuple, optional) – The starting time point of the interval.

  • end (tuple, optional) – The ending time point of the interval.

  • delta_of_normalized (bool, optional) – Whether to consider normalized weights for delta computation. Defaults to False.

  • normalize_weight (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize weights in the resulting graph. Defaults to False.

  • invert_weight (bool, optional) – Whether to invert weights in the resulting graph. Defaults to False.

  • fade_function (callable, optional) – A function to apply fading effects to edge weights.

  • fade_step (list or tuple, optional) – Steps at which to apply the fading function.

Returns:

The delta graph representing the changes between start and end time points.

Return type:

Graph

get_graph(time_point=None, *, accumulate=True, normalized=False, invert_weight=False, fade_function=None, fade_step=None)[source]¶

Retrieves the graph at a specific time point with various transformation options.

Parameters:

  • time_point (tuple, optional) – The time point at which to retrieve the graph. Defaults to infinity for all positions.

  • accumulate (bool, optional) – Whether to accumulate changes up to the specified time point. Defaults to True.

  • normalized (bool, optional) – Whether to normalize edge weights. Defaults to False.

  • invert_weight (bool, optional) – Whether to invert edge weights. Defaults to False.

  • fade_function (callable, optional) – A function to apply fading effects to edge weights.

  • fade_step (list or tuple, optional) – Steps at which to apply the fading function.

Returns:

The transformed graph at the specified time point or None if no data is available.

Return type:

Graph or None

Raises:

  • ValueError – If fade_function is provided while accumulate is False.

  • ValueError – If fade_step is not a sublist of position columns when provided as a tuple.

graph_sub(graph1, graph2)[source]¶

Subtracts the weights of graph2 from graph1.

Parameters:

  • graph1 (Graph) – The base graph.

  • graph2 (Graph) – The graph to subtract from graph1.

Returns:

The resulting graph after subtraction.

Return type:

Graph

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the directedness of graph1 and graph2 do not match.

  • ValueError – If either graph lacks the ‘name’ attribute for vertices.

property is_directed¶

Checks if the graph is directed.

Returns:

True if the graph is directed, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

take_interval(start=None, end=None)[source]¶

Retrieves a subset of the data within the specified time interval.

Parameters:

  • start (list or tuple, optional) – The starting bounds of the interval.

  • end (list or tuple, optional) – The ending bounds of the interval.

Returns:

The filtered data within the specified interval.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

ValueError – If the length of start or end is out of range relative to position.

Dependencies¶

Python: igraph, pandas, numpy library

Usage¶

Create and manipulate a temporal graph

               directed=False)

graph = tg.get_graph((2, 1))
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
cg.iplot(graph, target=ax)
plt.show()

res = cg.tgraph_degree(tg, weighted=True, normalized=True)

res.to_csv('results.csv')

Plot a graph

import ciga as cg
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from viztracer import VizTracer

df = pd.read_csv('../../m_data.csv')

# custom weight function
# input: interaction (str)
# output: weight (float)
def weight_func(interaction):
    return 1

tracer = VizTracer()
tracer.start()

# load data without weight
interactions = cg.prepare_data(df, ('Season', 'Episode', 'Scene', 'Line'),
                                source='Speaker', target='Listener', interaction='Words')
sub_interactions = cg.segment(interactions, start=(1, 1, 1, 1), end=(2, 1, 1, 1))

# calculate weight
weights = cg.calculate_weights(sub_interactions, weight_func=weight_func)

# adjust grain size
agg_weights = cg.agg_weights(weights, ('Season', 'Episode', 'Scene', 'Line'), agg_func=lambda x: sum(x))

# create network
tg = cg.TGraph(data=agg_weights, position=('Season', 'Episode', 'Scene', 'Line'), directed=True)

# print(tg.data)
# graph = tg.get_graph((1, 1, 2))'
graph = tg.get_graph((2, 1, 1, 1), invert_weight=False, normalized=False)
# graph = tg.get_graph(fade_function=lambda x: x*0.5, fade_step=[(1, 2, 2, 2)])
# graph = tg.get_delta_graph((1, 1, 1, 1), (2, 1, 1, 1), fade_function=lambda x: x, fade_step=[(1, 2, 2, 2)])
# graph = tg.get_delta_graph((1, 1, 1, 1), (2, 1, 1, 1))

# fig, ax = plt.subplots()
# cg.iplot(graph, target=ax)

tracer.stop()
tracer.save()

# plt.show()

cg.pyviz(graph, notebook=False, output_file='graph.html')
